sect1.title: What is KIWI?
sect1.para: KIWI is a system for creating ISO images to boot as Live DVD, Live USB, or as an image for virtualization systems like Xen, Qemu or Vmware. KIWI provides the following advantages:

listitem.para: Create your own Live CD/DVD which contains only those packages that you really need.
Debug a new distribution by creating all necessary packages.
Build your own installable ISO images to customize available packages, patterns, services, etc.
Test new hardware with a predefinied image.

sect1.title: What do I need?
sect1.para: To build images with KIWI, you need the following preconditions:

listitem.para: A decent desktop with X Megabyte RAM
A minimum of Y Gigabyte of free space.

There are other packages that are needed for virtualization, but in this article we do not use them.

sect1.title: Knowing the Building Image Process
sect1.para: The building process of KIWI is separated into three steps:

formalpara.title: Physical Extend
formalpara.para: This stage is a preparation step actually.

formalpara.title: Logical Extend
formalpara.para: This stage creates the operating system image.

formalpara.title: Deployment
formalpara.para: The resulting ISO image can be deployed with different methods like installed on a harddisc or played by a virtualization system (Vmware, Qemu, VirtualBox).

sect1.para: Detailed background can be found in the System Design paper, see /usr/share/doc/packages/kiwi/kiwi.pdf.
